column1: Will Félix Tshisekedi cease to be president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo before 15 August 2020?
column6: ['Non-US Politics']
Reconfirmin forecast. Not going to happen before aug 15.
Not going to happen within the time frame of this question.
5 days to get hit by a meteorite....
Seems to be little to no reports of action against Tshisekedi across social media and traditional media.

It appears that he cannot be removed by democratic means, he is not going to resign which leaves the option of an involuntary removal. He has promoted a new head of security that is probably wise given the fates of his predecessors and announced the end of the Covid-19 pandemic. His perceived victory over the pandemic might buy some time and avoid any immediate removal.
Nothing says or gives an inkling of this occurring.

Doubt he will be democratically removed, but there is always a chance he won't be able to perform the duties. With a pandemic, ebola, and large amounts of upheaval and unrest in the region, there is no such thing as a sure bet over two weeks out.
Always a chance with the virus running around
Unlikely to be removed
Unlikely.
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
As long as he does not run afoul of Kabila, I’d expect he will remain in place, at least for as long as this forecasting window.
Small chance a dictator cease to power, the fact that he rigged the election indicate that he has the power.
Running out of time for this question.
And what, bring back Kabila?
@fisherdbus - Need for paying close attention indeed: https://africafeeds.com/2020/07/04/anti-government-protesters-in-dr-congo-arrested-by-police/
Went back to check protests. There are some. https://twitter.com/punchlineafric/status/1276115697643503617?s=21 Will have to pay close attention.

https://ouraganfm.cd/2020/06/kasai-la-sced-salue-la-position-de-felix-tshisekedi-en-faveur-des-reformes-judiciaires-efficientes/ https://www.diaspordc.com/felix-tshisekedi-reconnait-quen-60-ans-la-classe-politique-sest-transformee-en-une-sorte-de-maffia/ Since my french is passable I could read these without google translate. He is taking on Judicial reform and corruption. In second article he says the political class is a type of mafia and a poor role model for the young. Those groups will push back but I see no immediate danger of him being pushed out by August 15th but protests there need to be tracked.
Only 7 weeks left, no news about legal, health or political issues.
Passage of time
Don't know enough about this.

"The Democratic Republic of Congo’s high court sentenced the president’s chief of staff to 20 years of hard labour for the theft of tens of millions of dollars of public money in a landmark case that has captivated the central African nation ... Mr Kamerhe, a former speaker of the national assembly who ran for president in 2011, was a presidential candidate in 2018 before he withdrew and backed Mr Tshisekedi in a deal that would have seen him run as the ruling party’s pick in 2023 ... The conviction effectively ends that arrangement, since it leaves Mr Kamerhe no longer eligible to run for head of state again ... Stephanie Wolters, senior research fellow at the South African Institute of International Affairs, said it was interesting, given the 'ample evidence' of corruption in the former regime, that Mr Tshisekedi had allowed a member of his own coalition to be prosecuted but not yet any member of Mr Kabila’s group. Mr Tshisekedi has sought to win domestic and international support by promising to crack down on the graft and impunity that has long hobbled Congo’s development ... The failure of many of the infrastructure projects undertaken as part of Mr Tshisekedi’s plans for his first 100 days in office had also meant that someone needed to held responsible, Ms Wolters added." https://www.ft.com/content/9f671621-0ce6-4bf6-a16e-2423753cd5a5

All the attention continues to be on the graft probe of Tschisekedi's chief of staff, Kamerhe, whose final verdict is due on the 20th [1]. There is some indication that the parliament is inching up on him by removing the vice-president of the general assembly, who is an ally of Tschisekedi, though the ousting seems less related to politics and more related to personality [2].
He has established international allies which should help keep him in office for now, though he has no room for error within his country.
COVID effect
Lowering because of the passage of time.

Lowering for passage of time and no indication he will be out. If his alliance with Kabila gets shaky then raising this would be in order. Some rumblings. https://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/africa/MPs-vote-out-Tshisekedi-ally-from-house/4552902-5567758-1xmmbs/index.html

Félix Tshisekedi is only the third present of DRC, with previous administrations lasting 3 and 17 years, respectively. There is no indication that his administration will end prematurely in the next two months.
Lowering for passage of time
Going back to a nice soft round number.

"An armed group in northeast Congo...said on Monday it would lay down its arms and end attacks against civilians and the army, weeks after its leader was killed and other senior figures arrested...potential breakthrough for President Felix Tshisekedi who has promised to bring an end to decades of unrest in the region." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-violence/armed-group-in-northeast-congo-says-to-lay-down-weapons-idUSKBN22G2UD
August? Did-I-read-that-right-August? Anything besides 1% implies very high yearly probabilities.

There is a graft probe against his chief of staff, and some possibility of his coalition breaking down based on this arrest [1]. Though the loss of the coalition does not appear to have much impact outside of the election. Additionally, Tschisekedi seems to be doubling down on anti-corruption, by bringing in Muna, an opposition leader in Cameroon and a transparency advocate [2]. This leads me to believe that any removal from office will be slow moving, if coming at all, and most likely not happening before August.
Too hard to trigger a political crisis now, and too easy for a politician to use COVID 19 as an excuse to surpress any protests or discourage change in government at a critical moment

There is a tradition of bad leadership in a number of african countries, including Kongo. Leadership is based on power. Liasing with Kabila means there is no available power to force Mr. Tshisekedi out.
President since January 2019. Only maybe because of Covid19. https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Tshisekedi

"Vital Kamerhe, the chief of staff to the president of Democratic Republic of Congo, was arrested on Wednesday after testifying in an investigation into the alleged misappropriation of public funds, police said...Kamerhe’s arrest was a blow to President Felix Tshisekedi, who took power in January last year after campaigning on promises to clean up corruption...Tshisekedi has touted his efforts to root out endemic corruption in Congo, but activists have criticised his government’s spending on a $304 million public works programme as lacking transparency...Kamerhe’s Union for the Congolese Nation (UNC) party joined forces with Tshesekedi’s Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) in the run-up to the December 2018 election. Tshisekedi promised to back the UNC’s candidate in the next election in 2023...The arrest could cause the collapse of the coalition, but that may have already been in the cards, said Jason Stearns, director of the Congo Research Group at New York University." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-justice/congo-presidents-chief-of-staff-arrested-amid-graft-probe-idUSKCN21Q33L
Outside View: Only one head of state of DRC has been in office for less than two years, Antoine Gizenga, which some consider him to have never been the leader.
Being late to the game, I'll start with a conservative forecast.
Congo has 48 cases of covid-19, likely not a factor at this time.
Toggling to 1 based on no new data, but not clear how covid-19 will impact a country that has managed to survive ebola for years. Currently, 30 cases.

So far, Félix Tshisekedi still maintains a power-sharing agreement with Joseph Kabila (the former president of the DRC). Apparently, that deal is under strain. Kabila currently controls a two-thirds majority in parliament.
they just wrapped up a genocide with ebola being mostly eliminated he will stay
Ok not raising as good point that there are UN Peacekeepers there.

Felix met with Kabila in last few days to work out direct consultations between them. Protests of his government in Paris by ex-pats trying to disrupt concert goers to Congolese singer by setting fire. This: https://twitter.com/the_eastafrican/status/1239101640873062401?s=21 Not a stable situation as the youth of his party want some changes. Raising.

I do not see instability in terms of him individually but there is a slowdown in the economy and draw down of foreign reserves which are troubling. https://todaynewsafrica.com/breaking-felix-tshisekedi-administration-spending-big-making-less-and-eroding-drc-international-reserves-imf-raises-concerns/ Raising.

The probability he is no longer the president is based on probability of death. There would have to be drastic changes in international strategic interests causing foreign pressure for him to resign that would be greater than the incentives for him to stay. The probability of coupe is very low when leaders in Africa are fearful of a coupe because they are vigilant to instigators and the power of their subordinates. At this point his is trying to solidify power, and in the DRC that is defined by who controls the capital. Military action by other state actors is improbable, especially since there is a UN peacekeeping mission in both DRC and CAR which consists of participants from many of the nations who would have to be involved in such action.
Unless Kabila wants him gone, there is not threat to his presidency regardless of the social-economic realities of the DRC. Unless he dies in power.

Since my last forecast there have been more violent episodes in eastern DRC. Tshisekedi's budget was rejected by parliament, which will make it impossible to meet his pledge on free primary education. Neither of these are likely to threaten his power in the short term. My previous 20% estimate was probably too high, so reducing slightly but not too much to reflect ongoing volatility.
No obvious internal threats [1]. Convincing analysis by @ulfelder, which I adopt.
Only through death.
Tweeking a few points.
No reason to think he’ll resign
Revising down based on recent results; Tshisekedi still reliant on Kabila, who now can operate behind the scenes
Late to this question, but will jump on anyway, because it's a domain where I have some expertise.
Recent Economist article suggests power is secure for now.
Will Félix Tshisekedi cease to be president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo before 15 August 2020? Cutting my forecast in half for no particular reason.
It’s Congo, not Malawi. Kabila prefers influence behind the scenes.
Will Félix Tshisekedi cease to be president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo before 15 August 2020? In 7 months a lot can happen, but not likely this.
@akmenim provides a good analysis. @tccoleman26 provides rationale. Given the timeframe of the question is 7 months it would appear too short to happen.
His Position is still to hart
Very unlikely that he is ousted that soon, regardless of potential corruption.
Border stablized
He appears to have a good relationship with Kabila. Lowering.

Whether or not Tshisekedi maintains power in the DRC depends primarily on his relationship with Kabila, but also on popular opinion and the weight of humanitarian events such as the conflict in Kivu and the presence of Ebola. With that said, it is unlikely that he will cease to be president by August 2020; Kabila’s influence remains strong and it is nearly impossible for Fayulu or anyone else to challenge that. As long as Tshisekedi does not diverge too far from Kabila’s will, and as long as there is no major disagreement or falling out between the two men, Kabila has no reason to seek a replacement for Tshisekedi (and risk potential truths about his role in the election becoming confirmed by the general population).

The supreme court of the DRC is the ones who rigged the election. And they are the ones who decide who is president. Kabila is in a power sharing deal. Kabila and his own party admitted of Kabila's wrong doing. The battles out in the Kivu and Beni are on a decrease over time. Everything seems about normal in the DRC. Honestly, I am surprised this is even a question.
power grid commit and mining conf. attendance news... also had time to think over previous readings
mostly guessing. hard to quantify. read the articles above and clicked through to some other links. There are scenarios where Kabila is happy with the current arrangement or unhappy.

Meh - maybe he'll make it. dont see why fcc or others in power would go to the trouble, unless he goes real rogue (he kinda said some heavy shit the other day... but we shall see)
Tshisekedi's appointment was clearly illegitimate, but that doesn't mean he won't stay in power. First Mobutu and then the Kabilas stayed in power for decades.
Things against him are mounting up, and will soon reach critical mass
He seems to be on good footing by negotiating with opposition and by having international support. Do not see negativity about him on twitter or in the news. He is relatively new so have to recheck.

Tshisekedi has proven to be an adept deal-maker and consummate politician. Since his swearing in a year ago (January 2019) he has been able to negotiate a deal with the parliament on the formation of a new government which divides the ministries between the Kabila-aligned FCC and Tshisekedi's CACH alliance. This ability to develop solutions will permit him to serve the full length of his 5 year term and to stand for reelection
Unless something drastic happens, it's not likely going to happen.

Due to his current secret connections with the outgoing President and corruption, he will not be ousted this year.

He holds his position at the whim of Kabila. There is a real possibility of unrest in 2020 which will require political response even if it is not a meaningful change. That is when the weakest gets thrown under the bus as a token response. Felix will be looking at the underside of the bus in 2020.
